p:
Antigenic change could also produce earlier and more spatiotemporally synchronous epidemics. When more individuals are susceptible, fewer transmission chains go stochastically extinct, so each new introduction of a virus into a population has a higher chance of causing an epidemic. Consistent with this, studies have suggested that antigenic change is associated with earlier epidemics in Israel
18 , and with more synchronous epidemics among cities in the United States
19â€“ 21 , Japan
22 and Australia
23 .
